title: The Challenger Space Shuttle Accident
summary: Forty years ago, a space shuttle named Challenger exploded on TV just after it took off. It happened 73 seconds into the flight. All seven astronauts on board died, including a teacher named Christa McAuliffe. She was the first teacher to go to space, which made many people excited to watch. The accident made the whole country very sad. In a video podcast called 'Settle In,' Geoff Bennett talked with Miles O'Brien, who knows a lot about space, to remember this event and talk about how it changed America. They discussed why this launch was special because of the teacher.

background_read: The Challenger disaster happened in 1986 when the space shuttle exploded shortly after launch, killing all seven crew members. It was a big event watched by many on TV, especially because Christa McAuliffe, a teacher, was on board as part of a program to involve civilians in space. This accident led to changes in NASA's safety rules and made people think more about the risks of space travel. It's often remembered as a sad moment in American history.
